en.value: Talking about others' personality traits - Superlatives
Let's take a look at how we can describe the people in our lives.
Read and listen to the word and the key phrase.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
She's very shy when she meets new people.
Select the adjective that Lucia uses to describe Xanthe.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.

The words "fun" and "funny" are similar and are sometimes confused. Someone who is "fun" makes you happy to be around them, while someone who is "funny" has a good sense of humour and makes you laugh.
Rebecca is a lot of fun. We always have a good time together!
Eloy is so funny. He could do stand-up!
Minh describes Sarah in a positive way.
Sarah is so kind and polite. I love working with her!
My dad can be a bit lazy sometimes.
To recap, let's take another look at the words we have just learned.
She's very shy when she meets new people.
My dad can be a bit lazy sometimes.
What does Molly think of Ella?
She thinks that she's kind and funny, but a bit shy.
She thinks that she's a bit lazy, but also very friendly.
She thinks that she's very fun, but can be a bit rude.
What does Mariam think of Daniel?
She thinks that he's lazy and isn't very polite.
She thinks that he's kind, but not that polite.
She thinks that he's a bit lazy, but very kind.
According to his friends, Ahmed is...
really friendly, and so polite and funny.
lazy, but also quite friendly and kind.
fun and quite polite, but also a bit lazy.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
What does Elise think of Oliver?
She thinks that he's kind and enjoys living with him.
She thinks that he's rude and isn't a good housemate.
She thinks that he's fun and that he's a polite housemate.
Describe two of the people in your life. Write or record your response.
I love my family. My wife is so funny and my son is very kind.

We use the comparative form to compare two nouns. When we are comparing something to a larger group, we use the superlative form. We generally form it like this: "the" + superlative adjective (with "-est" ending) +noun
My brother is funnier than my sister. (My brother is funnier than my sister.) > My brother is the funniest person in my family. (My brother is the funniest person in my family.)
She's nicer than him. (She's nicer than him.) > She's the nicest person in the office. (She's the nicest person in the office.)
In each sentence, select the two words that form the superlative.
My colleague Mia is [h]the[/h] [h]funniest[/h] person in the office.
My brother is [k]the funniest[/k] person in my family.
He's [k]the rudest[/k] person in the office.

There are two different ways of forming the superlative, and the method we use depends on the adjective. There is no hard-and-fast rule for which adjectives use which rule, and some can use either, so we have to learn them as we go. 

We use one of these structures: "the most" + adjective OR "the" + adjective (with "-est" ending). Here are some examples.
My sister is the most confident person I know.
I'm the shyest / the most shy person in my family.
He's the most polite out of all my friends.
In each sentence, select the three words that form the superlative.
Joseph is [h]the[/h] [h]most[/h] [h]shy[/h] in our group of friends.
My brother is [k]the most fun[/k] person in my family.
He's [k]the kindest[/k] person in the office.
When we use superlatives in English, we generally say what we are comparing to. However, in more informal contexts, we often omit this part. Consider the examples below.
He's the best cook in the house. > He's the best.
We're the laziest in our friendship group.  > We're the laziest.
Cleaning is the worst task in the world.  > Cleaning's the worst.
Who does Theo think is funny?
Here's a list of some of the words that take each superlative form.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I am the [k]funniest[/k] person in my house.
You're the [k]most confident[/k] person in our group of friends.
Who is the most shy person in Lila's family?
There are three words that do not behave in the same way as most other adjectives.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Match the adjective to its superlative form.
Complete the sentence using the superlative form of the adjective.
My brother is [k]the laziest[/k] member of my family.
Who travels the furthest to get to work?
I travel [k]the furthest|the farthest[/k] to get to work.
My ex-girlfriend is [k]the rudest[/k] person I know.
Who is the most important person to Peter?
David is [k]the best[/k] cook in my family.
Describe some of the people in your life. Who is the kindest? Who lives the furthest from you? Write or record your response.
Julia is the kindest person I know. She lives the furthest from me, though, as she lives in Australia!
